text.headline: Bluebell Railway Timeline
text.text: Celebrating 60 Years of Britain's Favourite Heritage Railway

text.headline: In the Beginning - Promotion of the Lewes and East Grinstead Railway (L&EGR)
text.text: By 1876 a group of local sponsors in the area of East Grinstead who were disenchanted with the failure of the London & Brighton South Coast Railway (LBSCR) to the west and the South Eastern Railway (SER) to the East to provide a railway with good connections to London, joined together to develop a proposal for the L&EGR. By 1877 a bill had been passed through parliament authorising the construction of the railway. Local sponsors included the Earl of Sheffield, whilst John Wolfe Barry developed the initial design for the railway and Joseph Firbank was engaged as the Construction Contractor. However, funding became an issue and it was therefore agreed with the LBSCR and formalised by a further act of parliament in 1878 that the LBSCR would fund the constuction and takeover the line on completion. The LBSCR chaired by Samuel Laing therefore maintained a close interest and control over the construction with Frederik Dale Banister being assigned as their Chief Engineer overseeing the work

text.headline: Construction, Opening and Handover of the Line
text.text:
By late 1878 Joseph Firbank had started construction. The initial focus was on the major engineering works starting with the construction of the West Hoathly tunnel and then the Haywards Heath connection and the Imberhorne viaduct. By January 1881, a train organised by the contractor was able to run from Imberhorne to West Hoathly but eventual opening of the full line was to be delayed by the late start to the construction of stations and the additional provision for a double track. After a failed and then successful line inspection on July 21st 1882, the line opened on August 1st 1882 with a train departing East Grinstead southbound at 06.57 and a northbound train departing Lewes at 08:12. The Haywards Heath extension was well behind plan though only opening on September 3rd 1883. With the line constructed, the company seal and associated documentation of the L&EGR were handed over to the LBSCR who from thereon owned and operated the railway.

Mention should also be made of the 'Northern Extension' of the Croydon, Oxted and East Grinstead railway on which the line depended for its London connection. This was only opened by March 10th 1884, being further deplayed by a landslip at Croydon on the day after opening.

text.headline: The Brighton Period - Initial Design and Operation of the Line
text.text:
The line had six stations but only Barcombe was within walking distance of a village. Chailey parish had two stations, one at Sheffield Park and the other at Newick and Chailey. It was customary for a rural line supported by a company or individuals to have stations close to the residences of its sponsors. Thus Sheffield Park station was built for the Earl of Sheffield, and Newick and Chailey for Newick Park and Reedens, the homes of two other sponsors. The other stations were at Kingscote, West Hoathly and Horsted Keynes. A branch ran from a junction at Horsted Keynes to Ardingly and Haywards Heath on the LB&SCR main line.

The 1877 and 1878 acts included a clause that:

Four passenger trains each way daily to run on this line with through connections at East Grinstead to London and to stop at Sheffield Bridges, Newick and West Hoathly

This imposed a legal requirement to provide a service and the only way to remove this obligation was to pass another act.

Designed under instructions from Banister, the line was constructed to take double track. However, only the section between East Grinstead and Horsted Keynes (and thence to Haywards Heath via Ardingly) was laid as such; south of the junction at Horsted Keynes the line was single track with passing loops at stations. The line was opened in 1882.

text.headline: Four Students decide to save a Sussex branchline and the Bluebell Railway is born
text.text:
On 15 March 1959 a group that included the future president of the society, Bernard Holden, met in Ardingly and formed the Lewes and East Grinstead Railway Preservation Society. The society elected John Leroy as the first chairman, and Â£940 was raised in donations to start the society. On a vote at the meeting, the society changed its name to the Bluebell Railway Preservation Society.

The society's initial aim was to reopen the whole line from East Grinstead to Culver Junction as a commercial service, using a two-car DMU. The plans came to nothing: the society failed to buy the whole line, and most local residents were not interested. The committee then recommended that the stretch of track between Sheffield Park and Horsted Keynes could be run as a tourist attraction, with vintage locomotives and stock operated by unpaid volunteer staff.

text.headline: Stepney arrives
text.text: 'Stepney' arrives with our first coaches coming from the Brighton mainline to the Bluebell

text.headline: The Interim Line Opens from Sheffield Park to Bluebell Halt
text.text: As BR still ran an electrified line from Horsted Keynes to Ardingly, the society leased a stretch of track from BR just south of this. In 1960 the interim line was opened, running from Sheffield Park to Bluebell Halt, 100 yards (91 m) south of Horsted Keynes.

text.headline: The Bluebell arrives at Horsted Keynes
text.text: In 1962 the society extended services to Horsted Keynes. Also in 1962 a halt was opened at Holywell (Waterworks). However, this was closed the following year. BR withdrew passenger services from Horsted Keynes to Haywards Heath in 1963; and with complete closure of the line north of Horsted Keynes, the Bluebell Line was severed from the BR system.

text.headline: Kingscote Station Purchased and the East Grinstead extension is approved
text.text: In 1974 the society purchased the freehold of the demolished West Hoathly station, allowing the first steps to be taken towards an extension northwards towards East Grinstead station. It then purchased the freehold of the site of Kingscote station in January 1985. These efforts culminated in a public inquiry, with the Secretaries of State for the Environment and Transport giving planning permission and a Light Railway Order for an extension to East Grinstead in 1985.

text.headline: Hill Place Viaduct Purchased
text.text: The Imberhorne (or Hill Place) Viaduct, just south of East Grinstead, was purchased by the Bluebell for a nominal sum from British Rail just at the time of de-nationalisation. As a maintenance liability, the quid-pro-quo was an agreement to sell us the required station site for a nominal sum at a later date

text.headline: Extension to Kingscote Completed
text.text: The extension was completed in April 1994 re-laying track through Sharpthorne Tunnel, which at 731 yards or 668 metres is the longest on a UK heritage railway. At the north end of Sharpthorne Tunnel, the line passes through the site of the former West Hoathly railway station. It was demolished in 1967, but remains of the platforms and goods dock are still visible.

text.headline: The Extension to East Grinstead Opens
text.text: The last section of track to East Grinstead was formally joined using a white fishplate, with the honour of tightening the four bolts being given to Barbara Watkins, a long-standing Bluebell Railway volunteer. The extension to East Grinstead was officially opened on Saturday 23 March, with a two-week opening festival starting that day.
